item.title: Data Essentials In SwiftUI
item.description: This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Data essentials in SwiftUI(10040)â€˜. Data Essentials When I start on a new view in SwiftUI there areâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Data essentials in SwiftUI(10040)â€˜.

Data Essentials

When I start on a new view in SwiftUI there are three key questions I like to think about.

Three Key Questions
  • What does this view need to do its jos?
  • How will the viw manipulate that data?

  • Where will the data come from? (Source of Truth)

    • This question of the Source of Truth is the most important one in the design of your data model.

      State&Binding

  • State: the simplest Source of Truth in SwiftUI

    • State is designed for transient UI state that is local to a view.
    • When we mark this property as state SwiftUI takes over managing its storage. Why is that important? Well remember that our views only exist transiently. After SwiftUI completes a rendering pass the structs themselves go away. But because we mark this property as state, SwiftUI maintains it for us. The next time the framework needs to render this view it reinstantiates the structs and reconnects it to the existing storage.
    • Remember State creates a new Source of Truth.

  • Binding: the tool for sharing right access to any Source of Truth

    • Because some is a value type, Swift would make a new copy of the value. Any changes the view made to the value would only change this new copy, not the original value that SwiftUI is managing for us. So this doesnâ€™t allow the view to communicate with superview. We need a way to share right access to the Source of Truth.
    • The dollar sign in the call creates a binding from the state because the projected value of the state property wrapper is a binding. The binding property wrapper creates a data dependency between subviews and superviews. Many built-in SwiftUI controls also take bindings.
    • Remember bindings arenâ€™t just for state.
Designing Custom Model

  • When you should use ObservableObject

    • Need a data model which is separate from its UI

  • How ObservableObject is defined

    • Itâ€™s a class constraint protocol which means it can only be adopted by reference types.
    • It has a single requirement: an objectWillChange property. ObjectWillChange is a Publisher, and as the name suggests, the semantic requirement of the ObservableObject protocol is that the publisher has to emit before any mutation is applied to the object.
    • By default you get a publisher that works great out of the box but if you need to you can provide a custom publisher.

  • The mental model

    • When your type conforms to ObservableObject you are creating a new Source of Truth and teaching SwiftUI how to react to changes. In other words you are defining the data that the view needs to render its UI and perform its logic. SwiftUI will establish a dependency between your data and your view.

  • Data dependency surface

    • SwiftUI uses this dependency to automatically keep your view consistent and show the correct representation of your data.
    • This is the part of your model that exposes data to your view but is not necessarily the full model. You can separate your data from its storage and lifecycle. You can model your data using value type and manage its lifecycle inside effect with a reference type. this gives you a single place for all your logic making it easy to reason about all the possible state and mutation in your app.
    • Or you can focus on part of your app by having multiple ObservableObject that offer a specific projection onto your data model and are designed to expose just the data that is needed. This works better when you have a complex data model and you want to provide a more tightly scoping validation to part of your app.

  • @Published property wrapper

    • be able to update the progress and have our UI react to it.
    • by publishing right before the value changes. : SwiftUI needs to know when something is about to change so that it can coalesce every change into single update.
    • For advanced use case the projected value of @Published is a publisher that you can use to build reactive streams.

  • a dependency to an ObservableObject

    • three property wrapper that you can use in a view to create.
    • ObserveObject: a property wrapper that you can use to annotate properties of your view that hold a type conforming to ObservableObject. This is the most simple and flexible of the tool. ObservedObject does not get ownership of the instance youâ€™re providing to it. Itâ€™s your responsibility to manage its lifecycle.
    • StateObject: The instance that is assigned to this property is going to be the Source of Truth for this view. Now we can read the model in the view body. SwiftUI will guarantee that the view is always up to date. You can just declaratively describe how to drive the view from the data and SwiftUI will take care of all the rest.

    • EnvironmentObject: both a view modifier and a property wrapper

      • You use the view modifier in a parent view where you want to inject an ObservableObject. And you use the property wrapper in all the views where you want to read an instance of that specific ObservableObject.
      • You need to use your ObservableObject in a distant subview and passing it down through views that donâ€™t need the data.
      • The framework will take care of passing that value everywhere itâ€™s needed and track it as a dependency only where it is read.

  • The lifecycle of your ObservableObject

    • ObserveObject does not own the lifecycle of its ObservableObject.
    • You provide the initial value and SwiftUI will instantiate that value just before running body for the first time. You donâ€™t need to fiddle with OnDisappear anymore.
    • SwiftUI will keep the object alive for the whole lifecycle of the view.
Techniques For Integrating Data Model Into App

  • View Update Life Cycle

    • SwiftUI uses view to create a rendering, and then itâ€™s gone.
    • View structs do not have a defined lifetime. The lifetime of a view is separate from the lifetime of the struct that defines it. The struct you create that conforms to the view protocol actually has a very short lifetime.
    • The diagram below shows the SwiftUI update lifecycle. Starting at the top, we have your UI. Moving counterclockwise, an event comes in, which causes some closure or action to run. That then results in a mutation of a Source of Truth. Then once weâ€™ve mutated the Source of Truth, weâ€™ll get a new copy of the view, which weâ€™ll use to produce a rendering. That rendering is your UI.
    • A slow update: if thereâ€™s expensive, blocking work at any of these points, the performance of your app will suffer. You might drop frames or your app might hang. Avoid Slow Updates

    • Event sources; These triggers are called event sources.

      • Regardless of what triggers the event, the cycle is still the same. Weâ€™ll mutate a Source of Truth, update the view, and then produce a new rendering.
      • Each of these modifiers takes a parameter such as a publisher or a value to compare. And it also takes a closure. SwiftUI will run the closure at the right time to help you avoid slow updates and keep body cheap.
      • SwiftUI will run these closures on the main thread, so if you need to do expensive work, consider dispatching to a background queue.
    • An important question to ask is â€œwho owns the data?â€

    • Summary: Source of Truth Lifetime

      • Views are a great tool to tie your data lifetime to. And all of the property wrappers weâ€™ve discussed today work with Views. You can make use of the State and StateObject property wrappers to tie data lifetime to View lifetime.
      • SwiftUIâ€™s Scenes each have a unique view tree, you can hang important pieces of data off the root of the tree. This works great with multiple windows.
      • whatâ€™s great about Apps is that you can use State and other Sources of Truth in an App just like you do in a View. Here weâ€™ll create a global book model for our entire app by using the StateObject property wrapper.
      • Process lifetime: theyâ€™re tied to the process lifetime. If your app gets killed, or the device restarts, State wonâ€™t come back

      • These have an extended lifetime and are saved and restored automatically. Note these are not your model.

        • SceneStorage is a per-Scene scoped property wrapper that reads and writes data completely managed by SwiftUI. Weâ€™ll pass a key, which must be unique to the type of data weâ€™re storing. Then, we can use it just like State. behaves like State itâ€™s a scene-wide Source of Truth.
        • AppStorage: This is app-scoped global storage which is persisted using user defaults. Itâ€™s usable from anywhere. AppStorage, like user defaults, is super useful for storing small bits of data, such as settings.
Bottom Line

Itâ€™s important to think about what the properties of your data are and what the right Source of Truth to use is. And you should also try and limit the number of Sources of Truth to cut down on complexity. Remember, bindings are completely agnostic to their Source of Truth, which makes them a powerful tool for building clean abstractions.

item.description: This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜App essentials in SwiftUI(10037)â€˜. App Essentials; how views, scenes and apps work together You canâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜App essentials in SwiftUI(10037)â€˜.

App Essentials; how views, scenes and apps work together

You can now build an entire app with just SwiftUI.

Views, Scenes, and Apps

  • Views

    • Views are important because each view defines a piece of your UI. When you look at an app everything you see is a view.
    • But not all views belong to the same app since apps do not have complete control over the entire screen.

  • Scenes

    • In SwiftUI we refer to these distinct regions as scenes.
    • Instead the platform controls how apps are presented showing pieces of apps in distinct regions.
    • A window is the most common way that a sceneâ€™s content is shown on screen. Some platforms like iPadOS can show multiple windows side by side. Other platforms such as iOS, watchOS and tvOS prefer to show only a single full screen window for each app.

  • Apps

    • Collections of scenes make up the entire content of an app.

  • Together

    • Together apps, scenes and views form a unified hierarchy of ownership.
    • The app contains the scenes and the scenes contain views. Our app declaration looks similar to a custom view declaration.
    • For example, both views and apps are able to declare data dependencies. Both views and apps also declare a body property defining their user interface content.
Understanding Scenes

To really understand how this app works, need to know WindowGroup scene which manages user interface.

  • Models & States

    • An app can provide a shared model for each scene to use, but the state of the views in those scenes will be independent.
    • WindowGroup provides this functionality for app automatically on iPadOS. Each of windows is reflecting a different state in the interface.

  • a new view modifier, Navigation title

    • Each of windows is showing the name of my app as well as detail labels.
    • Navigation title on iOS can be used to populate the title in the navigation bar and the app switcher.

  • Scenes especially on MacOS

    • Itâ€™s very common for apps to support multiple windows by using WindowGroup in your app. Besides supporting multiple Windows macOS also supports grouping its windows together. Via the window menu you can merge open windows into a single tabbed interface. SwiftUI provides this automatically.
    • SwiftUI will provide a menu item in the file menu, which supports creating new seen instances.

  • The life cycle of scenes

    • They are managed by the platform theyâ€™re running on.
    • On platforms which support multiple windows such as macOS and iPadOS, WindowGroup can instantiate multiple children.
    • Since the platform is in charge of the lifecycle of scenes, there is a new property wrapper this year to help you manage restoration of your view state. The SceneStorage property wrapper can be used to persist your view state. It takes a unique key which identifies the state to be stored. This state will then be automatically saved and restored at the appropriate times by SwiftUI.
Customizing Apps

  • New Kind App: Document based apps

    • It automatically manages opening, editing, and saving document based scenes.

  • the new Settings scene type available on macOS

    • The commands API is powerful and flexible using the same declarative state driven programming model used in views, scenes and apps

item.title: Basic of SwiftUI
item.description: This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Introduction to SwiftUI(10119)â€˜. The way SwiftUI works A view is a struct It conforms to the viewâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Introduction to SwiftUI(10119)â€˜.

The way SwiftUI works

  1. A view is a struct

    • It conforms to the view protocol, rather than a class that inherits from a base class like UIView. This means your view doesnâ€™t inherit any stored properties. Itâ€™s allocated on the stack, and itâ€™s passed by value.
    • no additional allocation or reference counting

  2. Small, single-purpose views

    • Behind the scenes, SwiftUI aggressively collapses your view hierarchy into an efficient data structure for rendering.

  3. Views are incredibly lightweight in SwiftUI.

    • Because extracting a subview has virtually no runtime overhead

  4. The same primary role of View: they define a piece of UI.

    • A view in SwiftUI and a view in a traditional UI framework fulfill the same primary role: they define a piece of UI.
    • The view protocol only requires a single property: body. Which is itself a view. The rendering of any view you might build, like SandwichDetail, is just the rendering of its body.

  5. A view defines its dependencies.

    • When SwiftUI sees a view with a state variable, it allocates persistent storage for that variable on the viewâ€™s behalf. One of the special properties of state variables is that SwiftUI can observe when theyâ€™re read and written. Because SwiftUI knows that zoomed here was read in body, it knows that the viewâ€™s rendering depends on it.
    • when the variable changes, the framework is going to ask for the body again, using that new state value so it can refresh the rendering. Traditional UI frameworks donâ€™t distinguish between state variables and plain old properties. However, I found the distinction to be incredibly clarifying.

  6. In SwiftUI, every possible state your UI might find itself in an authoritative piece of data often called â€œa source of truth.â€

    • Collectively, your state variables and your model constitute the source of truth for your entire app.
    • For example, the offset of a scroll view, the highlightness of a button, the contents of a navigation stackâ€¦

  7. You can neatly classify every property as either a source of truth or a derived value.

    • Recall, SwiftUI can observe when state variables are read and written. So when one changes, it knows which renderings to refresh. The framework refreshes a rendering by asking for a new body, making a new aspectRatio view from scratch, thereby overriding the contentMode and any other stored properties. This is the mechanism by which all derived values are kept up-to-date in SwiftUI.

  8. Read/Write&SourceOfTruth/DerivedValue

    • Every state variable is a read-write source of truth.
    • Every plain old property is a read-only derived value.
    • SwiftUI invents a tool called â€œbindingâ€ for passing read-write derived values.
    • Constant can serve as a perfectly good read-only source of truth.
    • Observable objects: your state variables and your model constitute the source of truth of your entire app

  9. SwiftUI automatically manages dependencies on your behalf, recomputing the appropriate derived values so this never happens again.

    • In a traditional UI framework, every time a view reads a piece of data, itâ€™s creating an implicit dependency. Itâ€™s a dependency because when that data changes, the view needs to update to reflect the new value. When it fails to, thatâ€™s a bug.
    • These kinds of mistakes are easy to make when you mutate your subviews directly in event handler callbacks rather than updating a source of truth and deriving your UI from that. The challenge of managing this complexity should be familiar to anyone who has tried to juggle asynchronous callbacks or implement interruptible animations. These completion handlers can fire at all kinds of unexpected times.
Outro

No one pretends synchronizing multi-threaded code is easy. Race conditions and UI inconsistencies share the same underlying source of complexity. Many of the views we all work on have to handle way more than four events. Model notifications, target-actions, delegate methods, lifecycle checkpoints, completion handlersâ€” theyâ€™re all events

Youâ€™re human. You can only fit so much in your head at a time. As we add features the number of possible orderings explodes, and the chance we overlook one increases to the point where bugs are inevitable.

When using a traditional UI framework the simplicity that results from collecting all of your view updates into a single method. When you do this, you break the back of the curve we just saw, because when thereâ€™s only one method, thereâ€™s only one possible order it can be called in.You may not have thought about it in this way, but this pattern forces you to define a source of truth for every possible state your UI might find itself in and derive your viewâ€™s properties from that collective source of truth. If this sounds familiar, itâ€™s because SwiftUI was directly inspired by this best practice. Weâ€™ve codified it in the framework by making â€œbodyâ€ the only entry point that is ever called.

This is why Views, but also Apps and Scenes and any other SwiftUI abstractions with a body work the way they do. Because youâ€™re only human, and this pattern of simply fetching new instances for the parts of the UI that changed scales with your brain, virtually eliminating UI inconsistencies.

item.title: Basic of Widget2
item.description: This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Design Great Widget(10103)â€˜. 1. How to Design Widget Widget UX in iOS14 The information your widgetâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Design Great Widget(10103)â€˜.

1. How to Design Widget

Widget UX in iOS14
  • The information your widget chooses to surface can be more up to date and contextual than ever and drag and drop editing gives people direct control over their widgets in an intuitive and flexible way.
  • People can now add these new widgets directly onto their home screen pages.
  • Smart stacks dynamically change and adapt to how you use them. Based on your behavior and context, a smart stack will automatically rotate to show you the most relevant widget at a given time. So the information youâ€™re looking for is already there before you even have to lift a finger.
Three Principles

To create a great widget you need to understand what the most useful information and experiences are that people return to your app for.

  • Personal: they can allow for a deeper emotional connection with a piece of your app or an experience that it enables for someone.
  • Informational: Surfacing the right information can save people from doing commonly repeated actions in your app.
  • Contextual: Context helps surface the right information at the right moment and allows for a better experience that at its best feels like itâ€™s magically predicting someoneâ€™s needs and next steps.
Editing
  • This is an important concept to think about in the ideation phase because it might change how much information you try to put into a single widget.
  • In iOS 14, your widgets will jiggle just like apps do in edit mode and you can tap on a widget here to flip it around and see what it allows for you to edit.
  • iOS 14 let you add as many additional widgets as you want and edit each one to show a different set of information. One of the best parts of this feature is that it eliminates the need to create complex widget layouts that represent different entities of information combined into a single widget and instead lets a person choose how much information they want to see from your app by adding several widgets and editing them to show just what they want to keep track of.
  • Consider what options you could offer to people that would maximize the utility and flexibility that people might get out of your widget.
Multiples

Another thing to consider in the ideation process is deciding on if you should offer multiple widgets

2. Decide spec

Size & Interactions

  • Small

    • The small widget is all about the most useful piece of content from your app in a size that constrains how much content can actually fit in it.
    • The small widget supports a single tap target. Tapping it should deep link to the content thatâ€™s on the widget. Where you deep link to will depend on how your app is structured.

  • Medium & Large

    • Our medium and large widgets are familiar shapes.
    • Both sizes fit more content and support multiple tap targets. Tapping a piece of content in a medium or large widget should also deep link you to the displayed content thatâ€™s on the widget
Three Tap Styles

  • Fill Style

    • Fill style is best for when youâ€™re deep linking into a single piece of content.
    • Every small widget uses fill style since it only supports one tap target.

  • Cell Style

    • Cell style is best for when youâ€™re selecting a piece of content in a widget that lives in its own shape

  • Content Style

    • Content style is great for when youâ€™re selecting a piece of content that lives un-contained in a widget.
Content&Personality
  • Ask yourself questions like â€œWhat are people looking for when they launch my app?â€œ. Also find distinct items of information that people find useful in your app.
  • When designing our widget set, we looked at finding personality through how our apps look.
  • Another approach for finding personality is taking inspiration from your app icon.
Partterns

  • Layout Set Pattern & Guide

    1. a layout that expands across all three sizes
    2. a layout that is completely unique across sizes
    3. Make sure not to scale up your smaller widget into your larger widget.
    4. Think about the information youâ€™re working with and what makes the most sense for each size.
    5. If you donâ€™t have more information to show in your larger sizes though, itâ€™s fine to only support specific sizes of your idea. All sizes for an idea arenâ€™t required.
Frame Layout Pattern & Guide

  • Standard

    • There are mix of single item and denser multi-item summary layouts. These patterns serve as a helpful starting place and a good way to try out an idea in a format that already works well.

  • Custom

    • Follow the default sixteen point layout margins across all sizes to make sure the content in your widget feels consistent when itâ€™s place next to other widgets.
    • For layouts with graphical shapes like circles and inset platters use tighter eleven point margins across all sizes.
    • Shape corners that sit close to the edges of your widget should appear concentric with the widgets corner radius. Since the widgets corner radius changes across different device sizes, we provide a Swift UI container that you can assign to shapes in your widget that will make them concentric with the widgets corner radius without needing to manually specify corner radius values.
Other Design Guide

  • Font

    • You should use SF Pro or other variants of San Francisco that are available like SF Mono and SF Pro Rounded.
    • If a custom font is important to how your widget represents its brand or personality make sure itâ€™s applied in a way so that your widget still feels at home alongside other widgets.

  • DarkMode

    • A widget should look great in both light and dark appearance modes.

  • Placeholder

    • Every widget must provide a placeholder which is shown when the system has no way of displaying your widgetâ€™s data.
    • You should show the base graphical elements in this state and block in areas of text where your information is shown in the layout. This way, when the system goes from place holder to the proper data the content can replace the static elements without having the layout or color shift around.

  • Logo

    • You should only use a logo in your widget if your app is an aggregator of content from different sources like these examples here. To keep this treatment consistent across different widgets, your logo should always sit in the top right corner.
    • Avoid using word marks in the space and anywhere else in your widget.
    • Another thing to avoid is putting your app icon in your widget.

  • Etc

    • Avoid putting your app name in your widget as it will feel redundant with the app label that already appears underneath of it on the home screen.
    • Donâ€™t put text that instructs a user or talks to them, instead, if you feel thereâ€™s something important to communicate do it in a graphical way.
    • When displaying chronological information on a Widget, donâ€™t use language like â€œlast updatedâ€ or â€œlast checkedâ€.

item.title: Basic of Widget
item.description: This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Meet WidgetKit(10028)â€˜. 1. Definition and Goal of Widget Definition A widget elevates key contentâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is the summary of WWDC20 Session â€˜Meet WidgetKit(10028)â€˜.

1. Definition and Goal of Widget

Definition

A widget elevates key content from your app and displays it where people can see it at a glance on iPhone, iPad, and Mac. Useful and delightful, widgets can also help people personalize their iPhone Home screens in unique ways.

Three goals of Widget

  • Glanceable

    • Widget is not a mini app. The content is the focus.
    • People only spend a few moments on their Home screen before they springboard off to somewhere else. They shouldnâ€™t need to interact with or do anything more than take a quick peek to get the most value out of your widget.

  • Relevent

    • Especially on our mobile platforms â€” where space is at a premium â€” we really wanted a way to make sure the right widget is up and available as soon as you need. Smart Stacks are a collection of widgets that will automatically rotate to show the right widget at the top. We used on-device intelligence to help show the right thing at the top of the stack.
    • As a developer, you can help drive this using Siri Shortcuts donations, the system that weâ€™ve been building upon in previous years.

  • Personalization

    • Support as many sizes as possible.

2. How it Works

  • Mulitplatform

    • It runs across iOS, iPadOS, and macOS.
    • built entirely with SwiftUI. SwiftUI also makes it super easy to support features like Dynamic Type and Dark Mode nearly automatically.

  • Background

    • The average person goes to the Home screen more than 90 times a day and only spends a few moments there. The last thing you want to see is your Home screen full of loading spinners.
    • WidgetKit extensions are background extensions that return a series of view hierarchies in a timeline. This avoids the entire â€œlaunch a process, load, and then present a view.â€ They are ready to go and immediately glanceable.

  • Stateless UI

    • Not support scrolling within the widget, interactive elements like switches and other system controls
    • No videos or animated images
    • Easily tap on the widget and deep link into your app.

3. Components of Widget

Defining
  • kind

  • configuration

    • static / intent (dynamic)

  • supportedFamilies

    • small / medium / large
Placeholder
  • Placeholder UI is the default content of your widget. It should be a representation of your widget kind, but nothing more than that. There should not be any user data in this UI.
  • The other important thing to note is this UI is retrieved only sparingly.There are no guarantees on when that will occur.Typically we will only ask for a new placeholder UI on a device environment change. For example, if the dynamic typesetting of the device changes.
  • Great placeholder UIs show a representation of what your kind of widget is.
Views

There are three types of UI experiences you need to think about

  • Placeholder

  • Snapshot

    • where the system needs to quickly display a single entry
  • Timeline
Timeline
  • Timelines are a combination of views and dates that are returned, which allow you to say at what time a particular view should be shown.
  • Timelines should typically be returned for a dayâ€™s worth of content.
Reloads
  • Reloads are where the system will wake up your extension and ask for a new timeline for each widget placed on the device.
  • Reloads help ensure that your content is always up-to-date for your user.
  • The system will take into account your ReloadPolicy and determine the best time to reload your widget.
  • Widgets viewed frequently will receive more reloads. Widgets viewed infrequently will receive fewer reloads.
  • The system will also force reloads for whenever a device environment changes. The system will determine the best time to reload your widget but there are also other events which may need you to ask the system for a reload from your app.
Feeding Intelligence
  • The system can intelligently rotate to the most relevant widget and your app and widget can help feed this intelligence.
  • Donating Shortcuts
  • TimelineEntryRelevance API: annotate timeline entries with relevance values
